qas.question: Why did Henry VIII wish to execute his fifth wife?
What was Henry VIII trying to avoid by creating a new procedure for granting assent?
How many times in the 16th century was assent granted by Commissioners?
Who was the last monarch to grant assent personally?
King Henry VIII sought to execute his sixth wife in what year?
Catherine Howard was the sixth wife of whom?
A clause was taken out of the Act of what?
Queen Victoria was the last what to grant assent in 1954?

context: A new device for granting assent was created during the reign of <b5_0>King Henry VIII<b5_0/>. In <b4_0>1542<b4_0/>, Henry sought to execute his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, whom he accused of <a0_0>committing adultery<a0_0/>; the execution was to be authorised not after a trial but by a bill of attainder, to which he would have to personally assent after <a1_0>listening to the entire text<a1_0/>. Henry decided that "the repetition of so grievous a Story and the recital of so infamous a crime" in his presence "might reopen a Wound already closing in the Royal Bosom". Therefore, parliament inserted a clause into the Act of <b6_0>Attainder<b6_0/>, providing that assent granted by Commissioners "is and ever was and ever shall be, as good" as assent granted by the sovereign personally. The procedure was used only <a2_0>five<a2_0/> times during the 16th century, but more often during the 17th and 18th centuries, especially when George III's health began to deteriorate. <a3_0>Queen Victoria<a3_0/> became the last <b7_0>monarch<b7_0/> to personally grant assent in 1854.
